title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Steps to Create Repo
text:
git clone https://github.com/brainworkup/brainworkup.github.io
cd brainworkup.github.io
echo “Hello World” > index.html
git add –all
git commit -m “Initial commit”
git push -u origin main
https://brainworkup.github.io

title: Steps to Create Repo
section: Put all code in the appendix
text:
Put all code in the appendix
The key: the chunk option ref.label to reference other code chunks.
More info: https://yihui.org/en/2018/09/code-appendix/
You can move your code freely in an Rmd document using ref.label, without cut-and-paste.

Cache time-consuming code chunks Use the chunk option cache = TRUE if a code chunk is time-consuming and the code doesn’t change often.
Child documents You can split your long documents into shorter ones, and include the shorter documents as child documents, e.g.,

Example: 15-conditional.Rmd Choose a child document to include based on the P-value* of a regression coefficient.

Generate a plot and display it elsewhere The key is fig.show = “hide”, and the function knitr::fig_chunk().
Embed files in the HTML output Sometimes you may want your clients or readers to be able to download certain files that you used in the Rmd docuemnt (e.g., a CSV data file).

Use the function xfun::embed_file().
This only works if the output file format is HTML (e.g., html_document, ioslides_presentation, etc.).
